baseline_groups.claim_summary: Hot days (days >= 32C) increase mortality rates in Mexican municipalities.
baseline_groups.notes: Baseline coefficient 0.00583 (p<0.001). Interpretation: one additional hot day per month increases the death rate by 0.006 per 100,000. Effect is robust across most specs. 92% positive, 80% significant at 5%. Elderly population shows much larger effect (0.112). Working-age population shows no significant effect.

global_notes: Panel FE study of temperature-mortality relationship in Mexico, municipality-month level 1998-2017. 64 total specs. The positive effect of hot days on mortality is robust. Key heterogeneity: effect concentrated in elderly and children, not working-age adults. Cold states show larger effect than hot states (adaptation). State-by-year FE absorb the effect entirely (p=0.997), suggesting the identifying variation is at the state-year level.
